verses.text: Accept the one whose faith is weak, but not for quarrels over opinions.
verses.comment: Paul counsels inclusion and mutual respect, especially when spiritual maturity varies. This anticipates later themes of unity within the church.

verses.text: One person believes he may eat anything, while the weak person eats only vegetables.
verses.comment: Here, 'weak' refers not to lesser faith, but scruples or misunderstandings concerning permissible foods.

verses.text: Let not the one who eats look down on the one who does not, and let not the one who does not eat judge the one who eats, for God has accepted him.
verses.comment: Unity comes from God's acceptance, not personal customs. The principle of charity in the church is underlined.

verses.text: Who are you to judge another's servant? It is before his own master that he stands or falls. And he will stand, for the Lord is able to make him stand.
verses.comment: A call to humility and trust in God's sustaining grace for each believer.

verses.text: One person regards one day above another, another regards every day alike. Each one should be fully convinced in his own mind.
verses.comment: Paul recognizes differing views on sacred days, foreshadowing later developments in Christian liturgy and holy days.

verses.text: Whoever observes the day, observes it to the Lord. Whoever eats, eats to the Lord, for he gives thanks to God; and the one who abstains, abstains to the Lord and gives thanks to God.
verses.comment: Every practice, whether eating or abstaining, when done with thanksgiving, is sanctified to God (see 1 Tim. 4:4-5).

verses.text: For none of us lives to himself, and none of us dies to himself.
verses.comment: Christian life is inherently communal and oriented toward Christ, not individualistic.

verses.text: For if we live, we live to the Lord, and if we die, we die to the Lord. Therefore, whether we live or die, we are the Lord's.
verses.comment: Belonging to the Lord is total, in both life and death; echoes ideas of baptismal union with Christ (Rom. 6:3-5).

verses.text: For this reason Christ died and lived again, that He might be Lord of both the dead and the living.
verses.comment: A strong Christological statement: Christ's resurrection affirms His lordship over all (cf. Eph. 1:20–22).

verses.text: But you, why do you judge your brother? Or you, why do you despise your brother? For we will all stand before the judgment seat of God.
verses.comment: Paul reminds believers of ultimate accountability to God, discouraging premature judgment.

verses.text: For it is written, "As I live,” says the Lord, "every knee will bow to Me, and every tongue will give praise to God."
verses.comment: Quotes Isaiah; ultimately all creation will acknowledge the rule and glory of God, fulfilled in Christ.

verses.text: So then each of us will give an account of himself to God.
verses.comment: Each believer bears personal responsibility before God—underscoring the necessity of inner sincerity, not just outward conformity.

verses.text: Therefore let us not pass judgment on one another any longer, but rather decide never to put a stumbling block or an obstacle in the way of a brother.
verses.comment: Echoes Christ’s warning in Matthew 18:6. The spiritual well-being of others is a priority in the faith community.

verses.text: I know and am convinced in the Lord Jesus that nothing is unclean in itself, but if anyone considers something unclean, for him it is unclean.
verses.comment: A declaration of Christian freedom regarding ceremonial laws, while respecting individual conscience.

verses.text: For if your brother is grieved by what you eat, you are no longer walking in love. Do not destroy by your food that one for whom Christ died.
verses.comment: Sacrificial love for others, following Christ’s example, guides Christian conduct. Personal liberty yields to charity.

verses.text: Do not let what you regard as good be spoken of as evil.
verses.comment: Good things may become occasions of scandal if not exercised with sensitivity to weak consciences—hinting at the wisdom in established Church discipline.

verses.text: For the kingdom of God is not a matter of food and drink but of righteousness and peace and joy in the Holy Spirit.
verses.comment: Central Christian life is not rules about food, but the life of the Spirit—righteousness, peace, and joy.

verses.text: Whoever serves Christ in this way is acceptable to God and approved by people.
verses.comment: True service is spiritual, not merely external, and results in favor with God and people.

verses.text: So then let us pursue what makes for peace and for mutual upbuilding.
verses.comment: The pursuit of peace and edification is foundational for the body of Christ, aligning with the call to unity.

verses.text: Do not, for the sake of food, destroy the work of God. Everything is indeed clean, but it is wrong for anyone to make another stumble by what he eats.
verses.comment: Paul stresses the supremacy of spiritual over ceremonial concerns—echoing how the Church always prioritizes salvation and unity over lesser disputes.

verses.text: It is good not to eat meat or drink wine or do anything that causes your brother to stumble.
verses.comment: Abstinence is commendable for the sake of another’s spiritual good, illustrating sacrificial love.

verses.text: The faith that you have, keep between yourself and God. Blessed is the one who does not condemn himself in what he approves.
verses.comment: A wise instruction for discretion regarding personal convictions, to avoid leading others astray and maintain purity of conscience, which aligns with traditional moral teaching.

verses.text: But whoever has doubts is condemned if he eats, because the eating is not from faith. For whatever does not proceed from faith is sin.
verses.comment: Actions contrary to conscience—even if the act is morally neutral—are sinful. Faith and certainty are necessary for moral actions; this undergirds later theological teaching about the nature of mortal and venial sin, and the role of conscience as a guide for Christian living.
